awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Unmanned Aerial Systems and Specialized Workforce Development to Support Oklahoman Agriculture and Industry
awd_abstract_narration:
Several Oklahoma industries, involved in agriculture, energy generation, as well as oil and natural gas processing/distribution, have recently started employing unmanned aerial systems (UAS or more commonly "drones") to improve the quality of services and reduce operational costs. This project will create a new experiential-learning educational program at the Rose State College (RSC) to train students, who will become the future workforce in the design, maintenance, and use of UAS across a wide range of civilian and military applications. Training this specialized workforce to meet the industry needs presents unique challenges, which cannot be addressed by merely considering UAS as smaller aircraft. One of the points of strength of this UAS program is that it will provide RSC students with a solid background that will allow them to meet the rapidly changing needs of drone technologies. Working in close collaboration with the University of Oklahoma (OU), RSC will establish a pipeline of students from high school to local industries in order to better prepare its graduates for future college experiences. RSC is located in Midwest City, Central Oklahoma, with an under-represented and minority (URM) population exceeding 37%. This ATE project will enhance development of a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce.

The UAS curriculum will be supported by an evidence-based approach in the use of an elaborate evaluation plan that will help to refine and infuse meaningful activities into a technical curriculum. More specifically, this UAS education program for technicians and engineers will provide technical background in the fundamentals of programming, aerodynamics, flight dynamics and control, UAS operations, payloads and applications, materials and manufacturing, as well as UAS regulations. Core math and physics classes will be accompanied by an experiential-learning approach to provide students with extensive hands-on experiences building on the theoretical foundations. Two sophomore-year classes, which are entirely experiential-learning, will also be developed. An additional direct contribution of the proposed activities will be the development of techniques that will make mathematical and complex notions accessible to a diverse set of students.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Rose State College and University of Oklahoma collaboratively designed and partially implemented a 2-year curriculum around UAS, which fosters meaningful learning, innovation, and attainment of career-sustaining skills as a result of authentic experiences. The Technology program at RSC was modified to train UAV technicians. Two Technology courses “Introduction to Electronics” and “Technology Practices”.

The RSC and OU team developed curriculum and course projects across multiple courses some examples include: (i) selected a material appropriate for the body of a drone, and designed a drone for manufacturing via 3-D printers (ii) Special Topics in Mathematics which was developed and taught titled, The Mathematics of Drones, and was taught by Dr. Shao with contributions from all members of the team from this project. At OU an UAS module in the Robotics Lab class was developed and implemented that introduced students to UAV related knowledge and programming in the Robotics Lab. DJI Tello EDU drones were used to implement the programming codes and experiments. An UAV module was integrated in Introduction to Aerospace Engineering course, which was taught in a hybrid instructional environment. The course is taken by all Aerospace Freshman and some Mechanical Engineering students. The RSC have started the process to add Introduction to Aerospace Engineering course to the RSC curriculum. Undergraduate research related to UAV at OU were conducted, which involved design, build and fly of tilting-rotor quadcopters, as well as wind field detection and reconstruction with quadcopters.

The instructional materials assisted in providing experiential learning opportunities to students at both RSC and OU to provide a better understanding of the technical aspects and to attract students to purse education and training in UAS area.

Broader Impact: To ensure a seamless pathway between RSC and OU, current transfer agreements were investigated and verified for RSC Engineering and Technology courses are appropriate and up to date with OU’s Aerospace Engineering program. RSC hosted summer programs with drone based courses and activities. Two Aerospace Camps were hosted during Rose State Collge's Kids College. The camp and courses were offered to middle school students for awareness of unmanned systems and to attract them to pursue STEM education.  OU hosted JrSEED summer program for highschool students to broaden STEM student pipeline. In addition to national and international conferences, the team participated in multiple Oklahoma state level meeting to promote the program.


Last Modified: 11/27/2022
Modified by: Zahed Siddique
